0.text:
G'day viewers, my name is Graeme
Stevenson and I'd like to invite you to come

4.text:
on a journey of creativity and learning and
adventure through the series 'Colour In Your Life'.

9.text:
There's an Artist in every family throughout the world and lots
of times there's an Artist deep down inside all of us as well.

16.text:
So grab your kids, your Brothers,
your Sisters, your Aunties,

20.text:
Uncles and Mums and Dads and come and see how some
of the best Artists in Australia do what they do.

79.text: You working on one of your masterpieces?

80.text: Several, in fact. Do come in.

82.text: Do come in, we’ll see what we can show you.

83.text: We’ll go and have a look.

94.text:
Well, g’day viewers, and welcome
back to Colour In Your Life.

96.text:
I’m with a very talented artist today,
a gentleman called Steve Hillier.

100.text: Thanks for having us in your studio today, bud.

102.text: No, you’re very welcome to be here, Graeme.

104.text:
An amazingly talented man that actually focuses
very much on the figurative work and nudes.

108.text:
Really, really beautiful work. We have some
similarities as far as our influence is concerned.

113.text:
Steve was actually influenced by a
group of young men in the 1840’s and 50’s

118.text:
called the Pre-Raphaelites and also another gentleman
called Raymond Ching who you obviously love as well.

124.text:
Yeah, the Pre-Raphaelites of course dictate
my pommy (English) heritage in many ways -

129.text: - because they were mostly all UK people.

131.text: They were probably mid 19th century artists.

136.text:
They broke away from the Royal
Society because they didn’t believe

140.text:
in what the principles of the Royal
Society were at the time and felt

142.text: art was a bit deeper than what was happening.

145.text:
And formed their own group, and formed their own ideals
about what should be showing and trying to represent.

150.text:
And Ray Ching as well is a,
what a magnificent bird artist.

155.text:
I’ve known Raymond for probably 25 years
and obviously a great influence on you too.

159.text:
Ray Ching I came across in New Zealand,
because he was originally a New Zealand artist -

164.text:
- before he also moved to
Australia and then to the UK.

167.text:
Reverse to me, actually, in some ways.
He is the most incredible artist

172.text:
I’ve ever seen in terms of the amount
of care and attention he pays to detail.

176.text:
I’ve seen paintings of his where he’s drawn a hessian
sack and just about painted every weft and weave -

184.text:
Absolutely incredible.
It shows total and utter dedication.

186.text:
Yeah. Steve is very much the same as the
dedication of Raymond as well because he’s precise

192.text:
- the detail, the information, he takes photos of his own models.
The work is extraordinary when you look at it,

198.text:
it really is amazing. OK, well, Steve’s going to show us
three paintings today and the various techniques that

203.text:
he uses to go through the various
ways that he puts all of this together.

206.text:
So let’s go and have a look at the
pencil drawing that you’ve started and

209.text:
then we’ll talk about how you actually
build that situation up as well.

218.text:
Alright, Steve, unbelievable work! How
do you start it, and where do you go?

222.text:
I’ve noticed that you’ve just got a sketch here, so what
do you normally do to get to even to that place right there?

227.text: OK, well let’s start right at the beginning. Now what I,

229.text:
because of the way I work I like to work
on as smooth a surface as I can possibly get -

235.text:
- so what I tend to do is buy a whole
heap of MDF board and then in one day,

239.text: or two days, I’ll put half a dozen coats of gesso over it -

242.text:
Probably sanding down in between coats 3 and 4,
and then at the end when it’s perfectly dry,

247.text: which is most cases the next day -

250.text:
- I’ll give it another sanding and as
you can feel I’ve ended up with

253.text:
something that’s even smoother than - well,
about as smooth as maybe hot-pressed paper -

257.text: - but obviously a lot harder and a lot more stable.

259.text:
That’s got a beautiful finish to it,
too, doesn’t it! It’s just amazing, it really is.

262.text:
When it gets to actually producing the drawing
the first thing obviously is I’ve got to pick the design,

266.text:
or an image in mind that I want to end up with. I do a lot of my
own photography of models which Graeme talked about earlier.

272.text:
I’ll arrange a photo session, I’ll probably have
at least 2 or 3 dozen different types of poses

276.text:
that I want the model to do. We’ll do those and that way
I’ve got stock I can work on whenever I feel like working on it.

283.text:
And as I said to the audience before,
these are sort of sections and techniques

287.text:
of what you would put together to make
that because they really are very, very detailed.

290.text:
Now, the first thing I’ll do is, from my
model shot I’ll produce a small, probably A4 size,

295.text: drawing. It’s basically only a line drawing as you can see.

298.text:
Maybe a few guide lines where shadows and
reflections and things like that will start to appear.

303.text:
What I’ll then do with that, and this is
where I start doing a bit of modern-day trickery,

307.text:
is I’ll scan that drawing into my computer
and print off a small image of it like this.

314.text:
Then now with this very small image
that I produce on the computer,

318.text:
I can now put this into my projector and
blow it up to absolutely any size I want.

323.text:
The aim here is to end up with a whole load of very soft lines,
and the way I do this is I go - excuse me,

329.text:
I need my glasses - I go over what the
projector has given me, very gently -

338.text: I reinforce the lines of the projector, -

341.text:
- check on my reference work to make sure
that what I’ve got from the projector is correct, -

346.text:
- because when you’re doing a photorealistic
painting even the smallest fault that

350.text:
you’ve made in the image reproduction process
is going to show up like a sore thumb. -

356.text:
OK, now once I’ve started going over that,
and correcting the detail,

361.text: I will then gently pull a pencil rubber over that line

366.text:
- which will take away the highlights, because
even with hardly any grain in the board at all,

372.text:
the pencil is still leaving highs and lows along
the grain. To me, when you look at a figure,

377.text:
you hardly ever see what I would
call a straight line. Even what appears to

384.text:
be a straight line at the edge
of an arm or the edge of a leg -

386.text:
that shadow that you see right along
the edge is never a truly straight line.

391.text: It is always a slow graduation from dark to light -

395.text:
- and it’s not a line as such. So what I’m trying to
actually get rid of is the appearance of a line here,

402.text:
so that when I paint over it,
it does look like that natural soft graduation

408.text:
of colour from the dark on the
edge to the light in the middle.

412.text:
Now, with a photorealistic piece of work,
hair becomes very important and

416.text:
it’s something that you can’t really
do in an impressionistic manner because

420.text:
if the rest of the body is photorealistic you’ve
really got to make that hair photorealistic as well.

425.text:
If you really want to go wild, one of
these little things becomes very useful and

431.text:
they’re useful for all sorts of techniques later
on in other, especially with acrylic paint.

435.text:
It’s an electric eraser. Simple switch.
They work on batteries.

441.text: And you can just pull the lead off?

446.text:
So from here you’re going to show
us a couple of different techniques today,

450.text:
so we’re going to move on to the next
one so that we can actually see how you,

453.text:
you know, block these things in,
and then do a bit of spraying.

466.text:
OK, and this one has progressed a
little bit further from the drawing stage.

470.text:
This is a classic symbolist theme. It’s Salome and John The Baptist -
been done many times by many famous artists.

477.text: This is going to be my version of it.

479.text: After she asked for the head.

480.text:
That’s right. What I’ve done here is I’ve
drawn my image, not quite so much

485.text:
detail as in the other one because there’s going to be a lot
more paint and a lot more spraying going on on this one.

489.text:
I’ve drawn the figure, I’ve masked the figure,
I’ve sprayed and then painted the background.

495.text:
OK, so what we’re going to do next with this one is we’re going to
mask out the background and apply some paint to the figure work.

500.text:
What I use - I don’t use the frisket
that you buy from normal art shops.

507.text:
I use this material, which I find is
much better and much more durable.

510.text:
It’s called “Window Etch” and it
comes from signwriter supply shops.

516.text:
It’s a lot stronger, it’s got a bit
more tack than the traditional frisket.

520.text:
When I spray I tend to really pump the paint
onto the board and with traditional frisket

525.text:
the pressure coming out of the
airbrush tends to lift it and you get paint

529.text:
underneath and you end up with
a big mess. For this I use a normal scalpel -

535.text:
- you get from any art shop or craft shop.
Now, all we do is we just go as carefully

539.text:
as you can around the edge because you don’t
want to end up with any areas that are free of paint.

546.text:
So there’s, I mean your work
there’s a huge amount of precision in it.

549.text: I wouldn’t call it precision, I’d call it care!

556.text:
A lot of the care is designed to save
yourself work later. I find the more

560.text:
careful you are in these early stages,
the less work you create for yourself later.

565.text:
If there are processes that I
can use that are going to save me time, -

570.text:
- then I’ll do it. Especially if by saving that time,
I’m also getting a more precise finish.

576.text:
Now you see how easily this is coming off.
Now I am going to shield out the rest

580.text:
of that and what I’ve got here is a whole heap
of scrap paper. The thing about sprayed paint,

584.text:
of course, is it will always
go where you don’t want it to.

586.text:
Yeah, absolutely. You know, you’ll be sort of thinking,
“I’ve sealed everything up”,

591.text:
all of a sudden there’s no marks
there and there’s just one little spot

594.text:
and it’ll have just shot in there and you’ll have
this geyser coming out the side of the picture.

598.text:
That’s probably about as much as we
can do at this stage - the rest is up to God.

602.text: So from here we go downstairs.

603.text:
From here we’re going down to the garage where my wife insists
I do all my spraying because the spray goes everywhere.

617.text:
Here we are, banished to the garage.
What I’m going to do is I’m going to put

620.text:
a very loose and light coat of acrylic spray
paint over that whole set of figure work there.

627.text:
Not wishing to bore too many people,
I’ve pre-mixed the colours I’m going to use.

630.text:
So what I’m going to do is I’m going to
start with my lightest colour first,

633.text:
put a general overall colour coat on it, and then build
up through the other two tonal values that I have.

639.text: We just continue to build that colour?

643.text:
Yep, we just go on and on. This is actually
going on quite well. OK, one thing

651.text:
I should mention at this stage is I normally
paint with a mask on because breathing

655.text:
in airbrush fumes from acrylic paint is
not the best thing you can do in your life,

658.text:
although of course in this sort of situation it’s going
to be pretty hard to spray and talk with a mouth,

664.text:
er, face mask on, so excuse me for
not wearing it at the moment.

677.text:
OK Steve, you’ve also got a website,
so how can people get in touch with you?

680.text:
Yes, Graeme, it’s very much a work in
progress at this stage. It’s www.sexyart

686.text:
- one word - .com.au. If people want to
get in touch with me they can either

691.text:
do it straight through the website or
they can email me steve@sexyart.com.au

696.text:
And it’s definitely, it’s an appropriate name
for your work, isn’t it, there’s no two ways about it!

700.text: Yeah, well I was lucky to get the name -

702.text:
- I chose it of course because that
word - “sex” - it comes up on, you know -

709.text: - the top ten list on all the Google searches.

711.text: 50 percent of all the hits on Google, yeah!

712.text:
People can, you know, look at my art there. They can order originals,
they can buy prints of some of the originals if they want to.

719.text:
I’ll even consider commissions
if they’re in line with what I do.

722.text: As long as it’s sexy art, that’s the main thing.

724.text: As long as it’s sexy art!

735.text: Did you learn all this at an art school?

736.text:
I did two years at art school straight from school,
as a scholarship, this was way back in the 60’s,

742.text:
remember. The second summer at art school I
got a summer holiday job at a record company

747.text:
and never went back to art school. Part of the
reasoning was that art school I found boring -

755.text:
Sitting around drawing plaster casts of
Beethoven and classical plaster figures really

759.text:
didn’t appeal to me that much and when
I started working for the record company

762.text:
and ended up doing things like watching
Bob Marley record in the studios,

765.text:
or playing football with Bob Marley on
the green opposite the record company -

770.text:
- HQ, life at art school suddenly
didn’t seem exciting any more.

776.text:
So most of what I’m doing these days
is stuff that I’ve taught myself over

779.text:
the intervening years ever since.
It did have the consequence,

782.text:
of course, of robbing me of an artistic
career in many regards,

786.text:
and I’ve spent most of my life working for corporations and other things.
But art has always been in the background of my,

793.text:
you know, psyche, if you like, and I’ve always
gone back to art and really now,

797.text:
as I retired early,
being financially secure enough

801.text:
- and now I just spend basically most of my life, if not,
you know, nearly enough all of it painting and living art.

807.text: What better way to enjoy your life, but!

809.text:
It’s what I’ve always secretly wanted
to do and personally it’s, I don’t know,

813.text:
it’s something very satisfying about creating - it gives
you a feeling that you’re actually doing something,

819.text:
I don’t know, I was going to
say “worthwhile” but it’s not worthwhile,

822.text:
it’s more than that, it’s, I don’t know,
it’s the “God gene” in you and, you know,

826.text:
you feel like you’re part of God, you’re creating.
It’s like the universe is always moving forward.

830.text: So you’ve found the Higgs Boson, have you?

835.text:
- it all sounds pretty pretentious but
I mean probably any artist will tell you,

838.text:
you know, they know exactly what you mean
when you say that. It’s just an inner feeling that you

843.text:
just have to create and you’re not really
happy doing anything else unless you are creating,

847.text:
and for me it can, you know, I can be looking at a
film and see a wonderful piece of cinematography and say,

852.text:
“oh my God, look at that, that’s brilliant” and
I have to get home and get some paintbrushes and -

856.text:
- you know, it triggers
the creative instinct, if you like.

861.text:
So it’s always been there,
but I’ve had a pretty good fun life nonetheless.

864.text:
Absolutely, yeah. Hey, you’re going
to put some dark colours on that now.

867.text:
Yes, I’ve changed the tonal
value up to the midtone level now -

870.text: OK, we’ll see how that goes.

871.text:
- and I’m just going to carry on applying this paint.
You do stand the risk if you,

875.text:
the closer you get, the more paint
you’re putting on in one place. On this reference,

880.text:
people will see that there’s a very
defined shadow area along this arm here

884.text:
- I want to actually get the basis of that in with my
airbrush, yet retain that arm line down there.

890.text:
Now the way I’ve done that is I’ve cut myself out a
shield from a bit of card exactly the shape of that arm.

895.text:
Now I’m just going to very precisely put that right on
that line. As you paint this particular stage of the work,

902.text:
and then later with the transparent oil glazes, you will never,
ever lose that line because it’s always going to be there.

909.text:
Oh wow, look at that! So the arm just
starts to pop out, out of nowhere.

911.text:
Yeah, and so you’ve started to define
that shadow area almost straight away,

916.text:
and that’s probably as much as I need to do with the airbrush.
Whatever I do now, that is always going to be darker.

923.text:
Why don’t we get you to take some progression photos
so that the people will be able to see how this develops -

930.text: - OK, I think that’ll be a great idea -

933.text:
- because people have basically seen the process and a lot of what
happens now is just repeat, repeat what I’ve been doing.

948.text:
Well what we’re going to do now is duck
upstairs and do some more techniques as well.

952.text: Yes. That would be absolutely wonderful.

954.text: Let’s go upstairs and do that.

964.text:
OK, Steve, well you’ve got another
one of your works up there, and what

967.text:
you’re going to show us now is the way
that you do these really luminescent

971.text:
glazes that you’re so well known for,
so can you tell us how you’re going to go about that?

974.text:
OK, well, what we’ve got here, and I’ll
bring you up to date with the stage it’s at

978.text:
- I’ve drawn my figure, I’ve masked my figure off,
I’ve sprayed the sky with acrylic spray.

985.text:
I find spraying is beautiful for doing skies
like this because you get that lovely gentle

991.text:
vignette from the darker upper
levels to the lighter lower levels.

993.text:
What I’ve basically done here as well - the figure
was masked, I just laid some greeny-blue down,

999.text:
dropped in some white where the waves are both breaking
on the foreshore and in the middle background there.

1005.text:
I then dropped in some darker shades
for the shadow areas in the waves,!

1010.text:
and this is where that wonderful little tool I showed
you earlier - the electric eraser - comes in to its own.

1016.text:
To get all this wonderful little splashing
that’s going on where these waves are breaking,

1020.text:
when you’ve got acrylic paint you can
actually use this to lift off some of the colour.

1025.text:
It takes off the white and leaves the darker tone
underneath. So what I’m going to do is I’m going to lay

1032.text:
a glaze on top of these - an oil paint glaze - and
start trying to change those tonal values in the sea

1036.text:
to more where I want them. The image is built up from
three different photographs I’ve taken - I’m using the sea

1043.text:
from this particular image for my sea, I’m using
the sand from this image, because the other one was

1049.text:
way too complicated, even for me - it would
take me forever to do all those dots in the sand,

1053.text:
and I used the sky from that image. So what I’m
going to try and do with the sea now is I’m going to

1058.text:
try and get closer to the colours in
my original reference work here. OK,

1062.text:
now what I use for my oil. My favourite of all the products
on the market is probably the Rowney Artist Colours.

1069.text:
I find their pigment values are superb. OK, so here we
go, we’re going to put some colour on the palette now.

1075.text:
Now, this is a bad habit of mine
- I don’t recommend it to anyone

1079.text:
I’ve got a whole load of paint on the
brush - way too much, more than I need.

1082.text:
Oh, you just wipe it on yourself, do you?
You know what, there’s nothing wrong with that!

1087.text:
What, as you can see, I’m doing is I’m just
laying a very light coat of this sapphire blue over

1093.text:
the top of this green here and as you
can see it’s totally changed the values in that sea.

1098.text:
I’m going to just get rid of some of that colour that’s gone onto
those waves - I’m just going to push it back into the sea there.

1105.text:
Right, for my skintones I’ll, I’m using three basic
colours nearly on everything I do: Naples Yellow,

1111.text:
that we’ve just talked about, this one is Transparent
Gold Ochre, and this one is Brown Madder Alizarine. .

1120.text:
I’ve dropped a bit of those colours onto here, what I’d like
to do now, people, is just show you what these colours can do.

1127.text:
Just going to grab a nice clean brush here, get a
little bit of medium and maybe a little bit of turps onto it.

1134.text:
Right, the Gold Ochre to start with - which
as you can see is this wonderful golden ochre colour,

1141.text:
basically. The Alizarine Brown Madder, which is a
very reddy colour as you can see. And of course,

1152.text:
the Naples Yellow which you probably can’t see on this.
And I’ll start mixing these two colours together,

1158.text:
you get all your nice in-between tonal values for
well-suntanned skin, so you can go from the pure white,

1165.text:
you know, English complexion to the heavily-suntanned
Gold Coast complexion. What I’m going to do now

1171.text:
is I’m just going to drop a glaze over the whole figure, and
every time you put a glaze on it’s just building up that colour,

1176.text:
building up that colour - if you’re familiar with it in my
work at all, or if you’ve seen any of it in this program,

1182.text:
you look at it in real life and you’re
not going to get the effect from the film,

1186.text:
but a lot of those figures will actually look like they’re 3D,
and that is what glazing will do for you - it will build up that colour,

1194.text:
it will build up that body,
it will actually bring it out towards you

1212.text:
So you don’t find that you, it ends up
streaking at all? It just goes on quite smoothly?

1217.text:
I’m just putting it on making sure I’m getting
a nice even coat. I’ll just go down the whole figure.

1223.text:
I’m trying not to go over the edges, especially
on this sky blue, because it will dramatically

1229.text:
change the tonal value of
the sky blue and you’ll see it.

1232.text:
So it’s just really a matter of just putting that really,
really subtle glaze over the whole thing.

1238.text:
It basically is just right down to that,
Graeme, you know, it’s just a question of having the

1243.text:
patience to be able to sort of like say, I’ve really got no
need to finish this painting today or tomorrow or even this week.

1253.text:
And I’m just prepared to keep on working it, working on it,
working on it until I’ve got something that closely

1260.text:
resembles the image that I had in my mind
when I conceived the thing in the first place.

1265.text:
Don’t forget, you know, skin, especially round things
like arms and legs, has got a direction to it.

1273.text:
Use your paint to create that direction.
Just pull it around it a bit.

1279.text:
Create, you know, put a few lines in
there - lines where you want them,

1283.text:
not where the paintbrush has left them - but it will help at the
end of the day to give that a more body-like look to it. Well,

1290.text: that’s about it as far as I want to go on this one for the day,

1292.text:
I mean I could carry on I guess if I was going to be
here for a lot longer putting colours into the sand, I mean -

1299.text: - this skintone value is equally good for the sand.

1302.text:
- it gives the viewers a great deal of information
on really what the value of these glazes are.

1307.text:
Alright viewers, another great day
spent with a very, very talented man.

1310.text:
As you can see, Steve has finished work here,
wonderfully luminescent glazes that

1316.text:
he’s got over this particular figurative piece,
that’s just wonderful. Steve,

1319.text:
I’d like to thank you very much for
having us along, it’s been a pleasure.

1322.text:
Wonderful, Graeme, thanks, it’s been good to have you here,
and if I’ve been some help to some people, that’s also wonderful.

1326.text:
Absolutely. Thankyou very much.
We’d also like to thank some of our sponsors as well.

1329.text:
Australian Art Review, also Photo Review,
that have been, you know, working with us closely these days.

1336.text:
Chroma and Canson, which have been a great support with us.
4ME, obviously Virgin Airways that we’re on these days,

1341.text:
and the show’s going global these days,
there’s lot of countries that want it.

1345.text:
Also, what we’ve got as well is our DVD’s.
We’ve been absolutely slammed with these guys,

1350.text:
obviously you can have these in your collection.
Wonderful stuff, great present,

1354.text:
so if you want them, get in touch with us.
But as I always say, it’s been a wonderful day.

1359.text:
Remember, until we see you again, make sure you
put some colour in your life! See you guys, bye.
